docs.lead_paragraph: BECAUSE she had health insurance, Martha Rudnik, a former home care aide from Westport, Mass., assumed that the bills for her hip-replacement operation last May would be handled expediently. The procedure, she said, was clearly covered under her plan. But in the weeks after her surgery, she received a flurry of past-due notices from the hospital and doctors, on bills totaling more than $20,000. It was only after four months of dunning phone calls to her medical providers and the insurer, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, that the matter was resolved, she said. ''Our credit is very good,'' Mrs. Rudnik, 52, said, adding that she would never want an unpaid bill to come back to haunt her family.

headline.main: Personal Business; Is Your Health Insurance Hurting Your Credit?

docs.abstract: Personal Business column warns consumers that personal credit ratings may be affected when health insurance companies do not pay doctor or hospital bills promptly; photo; medical providers, increasingly quick to send bills to collection services, and insurers blame each other, with patients caught in middle; consumer remedies and state laws requiring timely payments explained (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE plan was hatched four years ago over breakfast at the Diamond Pizza Family Restaurant in East Hampton. Four men, then between the ages of 50 and 65, decided something had to be done about the town budget. After all, town officials were proposing an 8.9 percent tax increase. So the men, who knew each other from church, came up with a plan. How about a top-down budget approach? Instead of complaining about individual line items, like the cost of police officers' uniforms, why not just give the town an overall spending cap and then let town officials decide where to spend the money?
docs.abstract: Article on Common Sense Citizen/Taxpayer Group of East Hampton, formed four years ago by local residents in response to proposed 8.9 percent tax increase, that is serving as model for other taxpayer groups in Connecticut that are offering alternatives to budgets proposed by town officials; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki told supporters today in this gritty river town where he began his political career that the state needed his leadership for the next four years to navigate treacherous economic times. ''These are uncertain times, but we will meet these uncertain times in no uncertain terms,'' the governor said as he formally announced his campaign for the third term that, eight years ago, he promised he would never seek.

headline.main: Pataki Says a Battered State Needs Him for 4 More Years

docs.abstract: Gov George Pataki tells supporters in Peekskill, where he began political career, that New York needs his leadership for next four years to navigate treacherous economic times; photo; many in crowd are minority-group members bused in from New York City by union leaders for formal announcement; Pataki, who said in 1994 that he would serve only two terms, says that since terrorist attack, state has to rebuild lower Manhattan as well as economy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The fury of last year's dot-com bust may be fading from memory, but its effects are proving far more severe than anyone had predicted even a few months ago, state officials and economists say. Gov. Gray Davis and state finance officials are to release updated figures for the state budget on Tuesday, and economists are predicting that they will show a potentially catastrophic deficit of $20 billion to $25 billion for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, and the next.

headline.main: California Stunned to Find $20 Billion Hole in Budget

docs.abstract: Economists are predicting potentially catastrophic deficit of $20 billion to $25 billion when Gov Gray Davis of California releases updated figures for state budget for current fiscal year and next; state and local officials say shortfall could force state and local governments to slash array of services; California Legislature is expected to spend most of summer in bruising political battle over who will have to sacrifice the most (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of New Jersey doctors has filed a lawsuit against five managed health care organizations, saying the companies are employing deceptive business practices. The Medical Society of New Jersey, which represents 8,000 doctors statewide, said its members were forced into taking unfair contracts, that company computers routinely reduced payments and that decisions for treating patients were often overruled. The suit, filed in Mercer County's chancery court, names Aetna U.S. HealthCare, AmeriHealth H.M.O. of New Jersey, CIGNA Healthcare, HealthNet and Oxford Health Plans. Jeremy Pearce
docs.abstract: Medical Society of New Jersey files suit against Aetna US HealthCare, AmeriHealth HMO of New Jersey, CIGNA Healthcare, HealthNet and Oxford Health Plans claiming health maintenance organizations are using deceptive business practices (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: RAJIAH WILLIAMS, a senior at Barnard College, thought she had done everything right to set herself up for a career in television. She got all A's and B's and was a producer for Columbia University's television station, a Head Start volunteer and a member of the French club. More important, she worked summers at Black Entertainment Television, CNN and Fairchild Publications, assuming that the experience and contacts would practically guarantee her a job after she graduated. It hasn't worked out that way. Over the last few weeks, ordinarily prime scouting time for employers on college campuses, Ms. Williams has landed only one interview for a job that actually existed, at NY1, the 24-hour news channel. Now, she is seriously considering riding out the hard times by moving to Paris to be an English tutor.

headline.main: A Parched Job Market Greets New Graduates

docs.abstract: College graduates are facing what recruiters, personnel executives and college career counselors agree is one of most competitive job markets in more than 10 years; some are advising seniors to lower expectations, scale back salary demands and be willing to work for small companies; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE collapse of Enron and the problems of Global Crossing illustrate the need for sober financial analysis when picking stocks, say Wesley G. McCain and Joan M. Sabella, managers of the $72 million Eclipse Balanced fund. ''You could have talked to Enron until death warmed over, and management wouldn't have told you what was going on,'' Mr. McCain said from his office in Manhattan. ''But it was there in the data.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Group Health Inc., the Manhattan-based health insurer, has long had a reputation as a paternalistic employer because of its tradition of giving its workers health coverage requiring no out-of-pocket expenses. But ever since G.H.I.'s 1,200 unionized workers went on strike three weeks ago, that reputation has taken a beating, with no end to the walkout in sight.

headline.main: Strikers at Insurer Aim to Keep Free Benefits

docs.abstract: Group Health Inc's reputation as partneralistic employer because of its tradition of giving its workers health coverage requiring no out-of-pocket expenses has taken beating ever since GHI's 1,200 unionized workers went on strike three weeks ago, with no end to walkout in sight; sticking point is health insurance coverage; GHI insists that its employees begin paying something toward their coverage; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The anxiety, the sense of grievance and most of all the anger fill the meeting room at a residence for the elderly in Augusta, Me. It is another day on the barricades in Maine, where the political rebellion against the soaring cost of prescription drugs, now brewing around the country, may be at its peak. Norman Quirion, a 70-year-old retired police officer, says it is just not right that he has to make ''a drug run'' to Canada, where prices are far lower, to afford the medicines he and his wife so badly need.

headline.main: Maine at Front Line in Fight Over the High Cost of Drugs

docs.abstract: Political rebellion against soaring cost of prescription drugs now brewing around nation may be at its peak in Maine, where easy access to Canada's regulated drug market makes price differences achingly apparent; groups from state periodically organize buying trips across border; Chellie Pingree, Democratic candidate for United States Senate, is building her campaign on issue; was instrumental in passing state law that tries to force companies to negotiate with state to lower drug costs for uninsured; photo (M)
